overview: As a scientist, it is not only important to be able to experiment, research and discover, it is also vital that you can communicate your research effectively in a variety of ways. Even the most brilliant research is wasted if no one knows it has been done or if your target audience is unable to understand it.

In this subject you will develop your written and oral communication skills to ensure that you communicate your science as effectively as possible. We will cover effective science writing and oral presentations across a number of formats: writing a thesis; preparing, submitting and publishing journal papers; searching for, evaluating and citing appropriate references; peer review, making the most of conferences; applying for grants and jobs; and using social media to publicise your research.
You will have multiple opportunities to practice, receive feedback and improve both your oral and written communication skills.
Please note: students must be undertaking their own research in order to enrol in this subject.

assessments.description: Attendance and participation in class discussions. Students must attend 80% of classes and participate in all class activities including discussions, speaking to the class, and giving feedback to classmates.. 28 hours
First written task: 100 word lay summary of your research, due week 3. 100 words
Second written task: 300 word abstract of your research, due week 5. 300 words

Third written task: 1000 word Nature/Science news article. As part of the task, students will peer review each others' work. Initial submission for peer review due week 7 (hurdle requirement), final submission due week 10. 1000 words. Hurdle requirement:. Satisfactory participation in peer review
assessments.timing:
Peer review due week 7;
Final submission due week 10

assessments.description: 8 minute conference-style spoken presentation, due week 11 or 12. 8 minutes
Fourth written task: 1000 word short communication for a discipline-specific journal due week 12. 1000 words

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
